text: If I had a faculty member, for example, who was teaching a course, based on their research, that whites were a superior race, I would ask for an investigation of the intellectual legitimacy of the whole package.
author: TenuredRadical

text: ...or whether it was a bizarre idea about pedagogy gone wrong. What I worry about is, for example, what has happened to BDS colleagues: being told that legitimate materials they are teaching is antisemitic, and being discpilined/fired for that
author: TenuredRadical

text: Kind of -- although if a 35 year old professor did it, I might at least have them checked out for a glioblastoma. But I would also say in every case you need a procedure to determine whether the prof has the intent to attack and intimidate students, whether it is a pattern...
author: TenuredRadical

text: But again, technically this doesn't fall under free speech, it falls under title IX. But also this was evidence that he was no longer competent to teach.
author: TenuredRadical

text: Well, when I was chair of a department, a very senior person melted down and started spouting racist invective in class, which was a crisis. But we eased him into retirement because he was suffering from dementia, someone I had been trying to explain to the provost for some time.
author: TenuredRadical

text: Yes, but because it is quid pro quo sexual harassment, not because it is unacceptable speech.

text: Similarly, one might argue that all plantation records are at least in part the property of the enslaved, and could be subject to dispersal and sale. Yet the harm this does to understanding the past would be substantial if such collections were broken up.

text: I think that is a good comparison (repatriation of Native American sacred objects is another), although again an imperfect one, as these are images, not objects.

text: That's not necessarily so in law, and I am not sure it's progress in terms of intellectual property torts: but that there might be compensation for exploitation strikes me as an important legal precedent that might push a reparations conversation forward.

text: But of course, if all we care about is raising money -- not policy, movie star looks, or a Peter Pan attitude towards campaigning -- getting behind Beto is a snap.
author: TenuredRadical

text: I registered people to vote before Obama made it cool. I worked on the @GovNedLamont campaign that kicked @JoeLieberman off the D line in CT. I joined my local Dem club after Trump was elected. But voting for any Dem nominated does not preclude acknowledging lack of substance.
author: TenuredRadical

text: Even Tulsi Gabbard? No -- seriously. I am giving money to all women, & urging friends to give small amounts to all candidates they are interested in to get them into the debates. And no worries -- the public seems to *love* Beto. I am the only person I know who finds him noxious.
author: TenuredRadical

text: Thanks @jules0117insc for the shout out to my @DissentMag piece in your own article: want to acknowledge how much *I* learned from @TristanTaormino when I wrote it.
